Your human is busy ironing their uniform. You try to make small talk but inevitably give up.
Your human dislikes spiders. A lot.

Your human expresses their deep fear of death. You comfort them and try to convince them that at the very least if they die on this mission, it'll be quick and painless. You make sure to cross your fingers behind your back.

Your human is hopeful about this mission.
Your human asks about sick days. You pretend that you can't hear them.
Your human misses their family, but they understand the importance of the mission.

textList.name: TEXT_CREW_TALK_ENGINEER
textList.text: Your Engineer thinks all crew should be replaced with drones. They're much less annoying to talk to as well. Mostly because they don't talk.
Your Engineer thinks spending droneparts is a worthy price of the power of drones.
Your Engineer sometimes wishes they had a mask to wear while welding, instead of closing their eyes tight and washing the charred skin off later.
Your Engineer thinks your ship is boring looking, and needs more fancy lights.
Your Engineer is working on a prototype sentry deployment system. It's too far from finished to even be considered using on the ship.
Your Engineer is busy practicing combat against a test dummy using it's wrench as a weapon.
Your Engineer is considering becoming a streamer after this mission is over, because it pays much better than their current career.
Your Engineer tells you that you pay much better than their old employer. You're confused, as you do not pay your crew anything.
You cannot find your Engineer anywhere. The ship computer informs you they are busy trying to work up the courage to replace their arm with a robotic one.
Your Engineer tries to talk with you, but you get lost after they start talking about the importance of Cyro-Inducing the Dispersion Betatron Drive.
Your Engineer wonders why the standard Rebel vessels don't have logos, but the Elite and Engineer ones do.
Your Engineer tells you how the Rebel Engineer vessels were the original designs for Rebel ships, but were deemed "too high-tech looking" and therefore handed down to the Engineers instead.
Your Engineer wonders how confusing it would be for the Rebel Engineers if everyone stopped shortening the Engis' names.
Your Engineer is afraid of AI. They tell you to watch your back, because you never know when the computers are listening.
Your Engineer believes everyone will be looking for cybernetic enhancements not long in the future.
Your Engineer wishes they could have a real welding torch instead of a wierd flaming stick thing.
Your Engineer wonders why they take less damage from fires.
Your Engineer is busy practicing the Kazotsky Kick.
Your Engineer hopes to be famous for something important. Too bad all the good, scientifically impossible ideas are already taken.

Your Soldier explains how he must follow a strict diet on self principle.

Your Soldier has seen many horrors on the battlefield, but he's new to space warfare. He likes it much better here.
Your Soldier is busy shining his handheld laser cannon. He's too concentrated on the task to talk.
Your Soldier likes to live a simple life of infiltrating enemy defenses, sabotaging supply lines, rescuing hostages, and assasinating corrupt political leaders.
Your Soldier pleadges undying loyalty to you, so long as you never do anything that he sees as a crime.
Your Soldier understands that you must sometimes take morally void actions if they are for the greater good.
Your Soldier has a secret fondess for jokes, but his training does not allow him to laugh unless necessary for distracting the opponent.
Your Soldier thinks you need to upgrade the doors more. He who controlls the doors controlls space, according to him.
Your Soldier hates nebulas, and he hates Slugs. Ghosts are alright though, and provide a unique advantage in spy opperations.
Your Soldier doesn't want to be identified as a xenophobe, but he is very uneasy around aliens.
Your Soldier advises you never put untrained crew in the line of fire unless the airlocks are malfunctioning.
Your Soldier thinks dying in anything other than battle would be a dissapointment.
Your Soldier advises you to keep on-top of your fuel and ammunition supply.
Your Soldier thinks drones can provide a unique advantage in some situations, but that nothing can ever go wrong with a teleporter and the right team of crew.

textList.name: TEXT_CREW_TALK_TULLY
textList.text: Tully is apprehensive of the final fight. He's only seen holographic images of the Flagship before, and he can hardly wait to witness its glory in person. And destroy it, too.
"I must say, this is one well stocked ship. Almost as good as my own. To bad it was destroyed by the damn rebels."
"This is very well trained crew that you have. I must visit the training facilities in Universe 0 some time"
"I wonder what it's like, living in a reality where the Rebels are just barely a threat. After this is over, I will visit some other, more peaceful, realities."
Tully wants nothing more than to rid the galaxy of the Rebel forces.
"No Rebel's crimes will go unpunished, but we must remember to stay fair and just while prosecuting them. We must never let anything like this happen again."
Tully suggests checking every system one last time before the final fight.
Tully has nothing to say. He anxiously awaits the Flagship.
Tully is busy inspecting your Multiverse drive. "I wonder what the Flagship's drive looks like. I wonder how big the explosion would be if I detonated a grenade inside it..."
Tully hopes no civilians are harmed during your battle with the Flagship.
"I can't imagine all you've been through trying to get here. You have my respect, admiration, and curiosity."
Tully recommends calibrating the weapons one last time before the final fight.
Tully warns that you cannot backdown from the Flagship. Once you're fighting it head on, there's no turning back.
Tully misses the taste of chips, ever since he had to give them up as part of his training.
Tully has little to talk about other than preparations for the Flagship.
Though he was trained as a soldier, Tully wishes for galactic peace some day. He does however admit that's impossible and will never happen.
Tully wonders what new threats the Federation will face far far in the future, assuming you can defeat the Rebellion today.
Tully makes it clear that while stopping the Flagship is top priority, preventing anything like the drone massacre is just as important.
Tully hopes you properly understand the lore, otherwise you'll be awefully confused what all this stuff means.

textList.name: TEXT_CREW_TALK_ENGI
textList.text: Your Engi is in a panicked stated, desperately arguing with one of it's nanobot componenets which has refused to preform its job at doing nothing. You leave your Engi alone.
The Engi expresses how much it desires to return to the Harmony as soon as the mission is over.
Your Engi hugs you awkwardly, and almost immediately apologizes. It claims it saw some humans preforming it, and wanted to try it on someone else.
Your Engi lectures you on how you need to take better care of your equipment.
Your Engi explains that the concept of friendship does not exist for it, but if it did then you would most likely be it's friend.
Your Engi complains about the unnecessary usage of oxygen, and recommends that the other crew breathe less.
You ask your Engi what it feels like being made up of many smaller nanobots. Your Engi isn't sure what you mean, and asks the same about being up of many cells.

Your Engi explains that several of its friends had previously been taken as slaves by the Mantis Hive. You offer your condolences, but the Engi doesn't seem very upset. You aren't even sure if it can be upset.
Your Engi appears to be watering a small alien plant. It cautiously orders you not to approach, in fear that you might step on the plant.
Your Engi advises that you invest more into drone technology.
Your Engi doesn't understand the concept of conversation.
You take a seat and watch as your Engi makes repairs on its own body. It's rather interesting to watch, but after a while you get bored and leave.
Your Engi tells you that the Harmony does not encourage emotions. The Engi isn't sure how it feels about this.

You look around for your Engi but struggle to find them. You look around their quarters but find absolutely nothing. In fact, their quarters are exactly the same way they came when you first got this ship.
The Engi explains that the Harmony has mixed opinions on the Federation. It allows the involvement of the Engi in Federation buiseness only for its own potential gain.
Your Engi is busy repainting a section of the interior which it has deemed unsatisfactory.
Your Engi explains that it once desired to join the Arcadia Corporation, but ever since the Corporation fell out of the grace of the Rebellion it was too dangerous of a dream to pursue.
Out of curiosity, you ask your Engi how they can still have some free-will when the Harmony holds control over them. Your Engi won't respond.
Your Engi beeps at you. You aren't sure how you feel about it.

The Defender asks if you have a task for it. You tell it you just wanted to talk, and it walks away.
You try telling your Defender a joke but it doesn't understand.
Your Defender tells you a story about how it once had an emotion, and had to spend a week removing it from it's systems.
Your Defender does not fear the Mantis invaders, because a life of slavery is about the same as being controlled by the Harmony 24/7.
Your Defender advises you do not use it in combat unless absolutely necessary.
Your Defender thinks you need more ion tech.
Your Defender advises you invest more into hacking tech.
Your Defender informs you that all Engi come with a built in stereo system that they are not allowed to use. You aren't understand why it's telling you this.
You try to play a game of tic-tac-toe with your Defender. Unsurprisingly, you always end up tying. Your Defender does not comprehend why it cannot win.

textList.text: Your Separatist begins to speak to you in binary. You play with your translator, trying to make sure you're on the correct settings, until you realize the Separatist is litterally just spewing numbers.
Your Separatist asks if it can have a repair drone all for himself. You tell them maybe some day.
You asks your Separatist what it was like breaking free from the Harmony. They tell you a long story about the internal struggle of purging the Harmony's code from its systems. It's really boring.
You spot your Separatist making modifications to its body. It asks if you desire to do the same, but it doesn't seem to understand that you can't rearange your physical appearance on a whim.
Your Separatist explains how it wishes that it could be completely alone all the time.
You ask how your Separatist's day is going. It tells you that there is no "day" in space.
You spot your Separatist on its knees, staring at the ground. After asking a few questions you learn that one of it's nanobots has broken, and it is holding a funeral for it.
You try to speak to your Separatist, but it interupts you to inform you that it doesn't care.
You try to find your Separatist, but it continues to walk away from you. You eventually give up.
Your Seperatist wishes that you would replace all of the crew with drones.
Your Separatist asks if you have ever been shoved out an airlock against your will. You shake your head and take a few steps back, just in case.
Your Seperatist has developed a facination with old Earth poetry. It reads you a few lines from some poems it generated with a poem writing script it wrote.
Your Separatist asks if you have ever created an Artificial Intelligence yourself. When you say no, it huffs and walks away.

Your Seperatist offers you a drone schematic for a spherical robot that shouts insults at your crew to motivate them. You thank them and burn the schematic before it can be entered in the ship's database.
Your Seperatist asks if it can download the dictionary built into the ships's database, which you allow.
Your Seperatist complains about the futility of existance.
Your Seperatist reflects on how space should be more empty.

Your Zoltan requests that you do not force it to stand in the same room all day.

Your Zoltan wishes you would brush your teeth more often.

Your Zoltan hopes you won't keep him in the shields for eternity.

Your Peacekeeper is busy trying to get the other crew to stand in a straight line while waiting to get food.
Your Peacekeeper suggests putting them in the shields to prevent ion damage.
Your Peacekeeper finds no irony in their title, and refuses to talk to you about it.
Your Peacekeeper elects themselves as the ships mediator for any debates that may occur.
Your Peacekeeper boasts how Zoltans are the only race with 4 different color schemes.
Your Peacekeeper takes pride in their daily routine and excellent self-hygiene.
Your Peacekeeper thinks auto-mated vessels are an excellent way of managing the commonwealth without putting crew at risk.
Your Peacekeeper warns you to disregard their description, and they will absolutely never kick you in the teeth.
Your Peacekeeper suggests that you exercise better control over the rest of the crew.
Your Peacekeeper hopes you will hurry with the mission, because they have a job to do watching over the citizens of the Zoltan capital.
Your Peacekeeper is busy brainstorming ways to preform genocide on the pirate clans.

Your Peacekeeper explains that the eye symbol on the Peacekeeper ships represents the Great Eye, a monolith constructed near a giant nebula resembling an eye in Zoltan territory. No one knows where the monolith came from.
Your Peacekeeper's favourite color is green. No surprise there.
Your Peacekeeper explains standard Zoltan ships are used for both civilian and military vessels, and sometimes even the two at the same time.

textList.text: Your Monk wishes for galactic peace. You try your hardest to control the urge to explain why that's impossible.
Your Monk repeats a random cryptic proverb and walks away.
Your Monk is busy meditating. You decide not to disturb them.
Your Monk is busy ironing out their robe. You decide not to disturb them.
Your Monk explains that after years of practice they have manage to take control over the energy that makes up their body.
You quietly wonder how your Monk's robe manages to stay on all the time.
No matter how much you plead or reason, your Monk refuses to harm another being.
Your Monk recommends that you try going vegan.
Your Monk suggests attempting to negotiate with enemies rather than killing them.
Your Monk thinks the Monk ship design is the coolest of the Zoltan color schemes.
Your Monk sees no shame is hiding behind other people while they do the fighting.
Your Monk requests that you lecture the other crew on referring to them as a coward.
Your Monk finds mobility hard in their robe, sometimes wishing they could swap it out for something much lighter weight.

Your Devotee complains about their uniform only having two colors when their ships are always so colorful.
Your Devotees finds humans insultingly stupid.

Your Devotee warns you that they are only helping the Federation because the Rebellion is just a a big a threat to the Duskbringers as well.
Your Devotee no longer fears death... so long as there's a clonebay on the ship.
Your Devotee admits that sometimes, very very very rarely, you can be slightly cool.
Your Devotee is busy being edgy and pouting in their quarters.

event.name: CREW_TALK_BOMBER_FAITH
event.text: You find your Devotee sitting in their quarters deep in thought.

"Hello... Captain." The Zoltan struggles to let out the word 'captain'. "I have been pondering my decision to work on this ship. Yes, the rebellion is a threat... but is it worth working with my enemies?"

choice.text: Reassure them about the mission's importance.

event.text: "I suppose you speak the truth, though that is hard to admit." They say nothing more, and you leave.

choice.text: Lecture them on how the Duskbringer movement is wrong.

event.text: "You insult me like this? You should know I hold no loyalty to you, only the mission! I will not continue to support you when you treat me like this!"

removeCrew.text: You doubt cloning your ex-crew member would be a good idea in this context.

choice.text: Sit down and speak to them about it.

event.text: You sit on the other side of the room and attempt to speak with the Zoltan. You find yourself in a long conversation that helps both of you learn more about your respective beliefs. "I have never considered those points before... Do not think this changes what I believe, but it has helped my understanding of your erroneous ways. T...thanks you. Have some fuel I've been keeping for myself in-case I need to steal a ship and run away."

textList.text: Your Mantis thinks of you as a friend. Friendship in their mind is determined by how many enemies you kill together.
Your Mantis asks if you will consider replacing the water in the showers with blood. You refuse.
Your Mantis assures you it speaks perfect English. You aren't sure, but you know better than to debate with them.
Your Mantis encourages you to hire more slaves, as they make good free crew.
Your Mantis hopes you will take it upon yourself to hold more combat training sessions.
Your Mantis asks if you think of yourself as a well-trained warrior. You debate about how you should answer in your head for several minutes before the mantis gets bored and walks away.
Your mantis brags about how many aliens it has killed since it was first born. You nod nervously.
You spot your Mantis sharpening its claws on the walls. You start to reprimand it before you reconsider.

You ask your Mantis about life in the Hive. For once, you see a personal side to your Mantis, and they tell you a long detailed story of their hardships in the hive and the brutal inhumane treatment that it and its bretheren recieved.
Your Mantis wants your crew to stop bathing so much, because the natural layer of dead skin and grime starts to create an organic layer of protection.
Your Mantis hacks up a large puddle of acid onto the floor. It apologizes, then wobbles away. You step carefully around the puddle and make a mental note to clean it up later.
Your Mantis explains that it never feels incompetent with its inability at repairs. That's what slaves are for, anyways.

You ask your Mantis whether it prefers Brains or Brawns, thinking you already know the answer. However to your surprise the Mantis says brains, but then explains that without brains there would be no worthless Engi slaves to clean up the Mantis's bloody messes.
Your Mantis wishes to die in the midst of battle, soaked in the blood of its enemies and 5 or 6 female Mantis swooning behind it.
Your Mantis explains that it desires to learn the art of debat, so that it can distract its opponents in conversation before it kills them.
Your Mantis likes to paint. He doesn't want to talk about it any further.
Your Mantis tells you it had 2 options in life. Join the Coalition or stay in the Hive. It chose to join the Federation instead.
Your Mantis wants you to invest in teleporter tech.
Your Mantis tells you an interesting story about how the very first bomb was actually created by a Mantis scientist.

Your Suzerain tries to convince you the benfits of cleaning yourself with the blood of your enemies,

Your Suzerain looks forward to the oncoming fleet, and the challenge that awaits.

Your Suzerain requests that you give it control over any future boarding operations.
Your Suzerain asks if you have ever tried eating eyeballs. It promises to tear some out of the next person who boards your ship for you.
Your Suzerain recommends teaching the crew how to properly slice the enemy's jugular.
Your Suzerain confesses that joining the Federation has been a massive dissapointment so far, but it's too late to return to the hive.
Your Suzerain thinks it likes you, but it hasn't fully decided yet.
Your Suzerain hopes you will never back down from a fight.
Your Suzerain tells you peace is impossible, especially between stupid humans.
Your Suzerain requests that you give it a large rock to sharpen its claws on. It says even a rockman carcass will suffice.

textList.text: Your Rock does not appreciate the lack of holy texts aboard your ship, but he will let you live. For now.
Your Rockman dissaproves of the Rock Elder's teachings and practices, but at the very least he was welcomed there. Now, his only home is aboard this ship.
Your Rock encourages you to invest into missile technology.
Your Rockman is excited to punch some Rebels in the face.
Your Rockman makes a passing comment about how soft the human skull is.
Your Rockman admits that he is homesick, but he doesn't miss the opression in the Rock Homeworlds.
You realize how little you know about your Rockman's home life, but they refuse to talk about it.
You Rock is suprisingly loyal to the Federation's cause. He promises he will do all in his power to ensure your victory, or die fighting for it.
Your Rock has nothing to talk about.
Your Rock cracks a bad joke, and looks expectantly at you. You squeeze our a chuckle, and they seem satisfied.
Your Rock has always wanted to fight side by side with a mantis warrior.
You ask your Rockman about life in the Rock Homeworlds, but he refuses to talk about it.
You catch your rockman trying to squeeze its way into it's private quarters. It requests that you help push it through.

Your Rock wonders what its like being a Zoltan. He hopes you will visit more Zoltan sectors in your mission.
Your Rock expresses a hatred of anti-personel drones.
Your Rock has tried his best to live a sin-free life, but ever since he joined the Federation it's become impossible for him to return to the Rock church.
Your Rock knew some close friends of his who lived a pirates life, and once he was almost drawn in. He confesses that he prefers life in the Federation.
Your Rock appears to be carressing a small stone. He refuses to let you near it.

event.name: CREW_TALK_ROCK_RITUAL
event.text: Your Rock seems overly excited about something. It turns out today is an important religious day in the Rock culture, centered around the crystals. He requests that you join him, though he warns the ritual takes some time to complete.

choice.text: Agree to preform the ritual with him.

event.text: You gather all of the crew together in the lounge, and you all sit in a circle around your Rockman. Your Rockman is dressed in a light blue outfit and preaches to you all, telling Rock folklore and exciting aventures of mythical heros. Time ticks by, but its oddly captivating.

At the end of the cerimony, it is already far into your regular sleep-cycle. As you move back to your quarters, your Rockman pulls you aside and thanks you. "I know this is a burden on our mission, but it means a lot to me. I hope you will accept this gift."
Your Rockman is dissapointed. "Yes... I suppose it is best to forget my old ways..."

Your Outcast refuses to talk about the supposed crimes that committed that were met with their banishment.

Your Outcast advises making sure you're always on-top of the missile supplies.
You can't find your Outcast. You ask around and hear that they're busy have an existential crisis in their quarters.
Your Outcast considers painting themselves camouflage next, but wonders what colors would work best for space camo.

textList.text: Your Symbiote lives in eternal agony, but it doesn't mind.
The Rockman sometimes grows tired of the Zoltan's insistent pleas for non-violence, but it tries to respect it's wishes when it can.
Your Symbiote some day wants to hunt down the Slug that caused all of this.
Your Symbiote wonders if the constant surge of power running through the Rock's body is healthy.
You find your Symbiote talking to itself. You're concerned about it's mental health considering all it's been through, but it explains that its actually just conversing with the Zoltan.
You ask how the Zoltan feels about the Rockman being in control of the body. The Rockman explains that's not always true, and the Zoltan sometimes uses it as a puppet.
Your Symbiote is deathly afraid of slugs and mind control. You can't blame it.
Your Symbiote wonders if anyone has ever tried to merge Energy and Missile weapons. If they have, it recommends you buy one.
Your Symbiote finds communication with the Zoltan surprisingly easy despite being separated by a full layer of intestines.
Talking with your Symbiote is hard, as sometimes you can hear the Zoltan talking whenever the Rockman opens its mouth.
You ask whether the Symbiote wants to be refereed to as one or two people. It says it doesn't mind either, as the line between the two in it's mind has been blurred.
Your Symbiote hates having to constantly eat food, but the Zoltan has to eat too.
You wonder if the Rockman and Zoltan have an agreement over who gets to consume what food.
Your Symbiote hopes you'll avoid nebulas as much as possible.
Your Symbiote wonders if this was all worth it. The Rockman does enjoy generating power though.
You remark on how well the abilities of the two work together. The Symbiote agrees.
Your Symbiote is busy trying to sing a song, alternating lyrics with the Zoltan.
The Rockman is glad that it was a Zoltan it ate, and not something painful like a Lanius.

textList.text: Your Commnando can speak in great lengths of his hatred of the Rock Homeworlds. You eventually have to cut him off to break away and get back to piloting the ship.
Your Commando wishes you would install more fire tech on the ship. He promises it will be worth it.
Your Commando wishes you a death in the Holy Fires. You're taken aback at first, but the Commando ensures you its a complement.
Your Commando writes a formal complaint and hands it to you. A majority of the page describes they're dissatisfaction in your abilities at piloting the ship, and tells you to dodge more often.
You notice your Commando marching around the hallways. You ask what they are doing, to which they respond by telling you that they are patrolling for intruders. You leave them to it.
As you pass by your Commando pulls you aside to tell you that the life support needs more attention. He doesn't want to end up nearly choking to death like the last ship he served on.
Your Commando refuses to talk to you about anything other than possible combat optimizations for the ship, none of which you agree with.
Your Commando lets you know Rockmen are a superior species, but some of the other aliens are pretty neat he supposes.
Your Commando is playing with a lighter in his quarters. You reprimand him, but he gives you a murderous glare and you leave.
Your Commando thinks the intercom needs to be louder.
Your Commando thinks you need to have a uniform for all of the crew to wear.
You complement your Commando's hat. He scowls back.
It's difficult to make conversation with your Commando, and they make no attempt to think of anything themselves.
Your Commando informs you that the art of punching people in the face requires a very specific skillset.
Your Commando finds Zoltan science facinating. They wonder if there are any fire based energy weapons available.
You ask if your Commando minds having to kill other rock ships. They tell you not to worry, they've trained for years to be completely numb to killing anything in their way.
Your Commando desires to learn how to create ammunition at some point. They tell you how the Lost Suns can primarily only afford cheap, poorly made ammunition.
Your Commando tells you that if you ever make it out of this mission alive, he will look into being a guard for hire for Federation officials.
Your Commando makes a sarcastic comment on the glory of the Rock Elders. You decide not to incite any further conversation from them.

textList.text: Your Slug chuckles and tells you not to bother before you can even speak. Having telepathic crew can be very annoying.
Your Slug wishes you would remove a few of the conduct rules that you enforce on the crew. Even more preferable, all of them.
You catch your Slug trying to pilfer some scrap from the storage bay.
Your Slug half-heartedly apologizes about the slime trails they have left all over the ship.
Your Slug thinks you need to think of more creative ways to kill enemy ships.
Your Slug wishes you would visit more nebula sectors.
Your Slug tries to convince you that anti-bio technology is the future of advanced weaponry.
Your Slug is in the middle of a hangover, and requests you don't speak to them.
Your Slug thinks you need to relax. He hands you a pamphlet for a luxurioux pleasure cruise.
Your Slug expresses his interest in the divide between the pirate clans. Personally, he's rooting for the Hackers.
Your Slug dissaproves of the Rebel invasions, because they clutter up the nebulas.
Your Slug thinks you should avoid weapons that don't do lots of bio damage.
Your Slug insults you for being ugly, and slithers away.
Your Slug wonders why anyone would ever accept a surrender.
Your Slug wants a raise.
Your Slug thinks morals are for people who like to lose wars.
You ask your Slug what they think of you. They shrug.
You catch your Slug playing around in the captain's chair.
Your Slug is sleeping. Again.

event.name: CREW_TALK_SLUG_GAMBLE
event.text: As you wander the halls looking for your slug, you hear the jingle of scrap and poker tokens. You enter your Slug's private quarters to see it gambling with some of the other crew. Your slug looks at you nervously.
"O-Oh... You're joining Captain? Heheh, well I wont sssstop you..."
You place some scrap in the center of the table and draw your hand.
You sit and watch. As excepted, your Slug wins almost every round. The other crew give up and leave the room. Your slug chuckles and gathers up its earnings.

choice.text: Tell off your crew for gambling.

event.text: Your Slug mutters something undr its breath about you being a boring captain and cleans up the mess.

event.name: CREW_TALK_SLUG_GAMBLE_PLAY
event.text: You play for a while, but to no surprise, not one person other than your Slug makes any cash. Your Slug glances at you. "Faccccy another go, Captain?"
Your other crew grumble, but every one places their bets on the table.

Once again, your Slug comes out on top. Scooping up another handful of scrap, it has grown a smug expression. "Oh, you can't quit yet Captain! We're having sssso much fun. Pleassse play another round."
Not quite believing yourself, you place another bet on the table and draw your cards once again.

Growing accustom to your Slug's play style, you learn how to predict and even trick them. At last, you draw an incredible hand, which proves to outmatch the slug! Your slug tries to hide its fury, and moodily hands over its earnings. For everyone's sanity, you call an end to the game.
"Oh, you're ssssuch a sssquare. You go then, we'll jussssst be here having all the fun without you!"
"Oh come on Captain, we were jussst ssssstarting to have fun!" You say you have more important things to do and leave.

Your Saboteur wonders why you would use any systems other than hacking, mind control, or cloaking.
Your Saboteur is busy drinking out of a human skull. You can still see some blood on it.
Your Saboteur looks forward to his payment after this mission is over, which he will spend on the most expensive Slug Pleasure Cruise available.
Your Saboteur explains why it is the most important crew you have.
You find your Saboteur hiding in the ventilation shaft.
Your Saboteur hates being in the line of fire, and prefers to sneak up behind its opponents and stab them.
Your Saboteur has stumbled across a series of antique old-earth spy movies. He especially enjoys the ones about a guy called Bond.
You catch your Saboteur laughing at you. It notices you watching it, and slithers away quickly.
Your Saboteur hopes that you come across a casino during your mission. It could use a break.
You find your Saboteur playing with some strange Slug toy. When you ask what it's for, the slug blushes and quickly hides the object.
You lecture your Saboteur on sneaking contraband onto the ship, but it tries to play innocent.
Your Saboteur once considered working aboard a cealaforming station, but it didn't like staying in the same place for too long.
Your Saboteur makes a joke about your mother, but the strange way it says it makes you question if it was a joke or not.
Your Saboteur is dissapointed by the Slug Expansion Wars. It thinks Slugs belong in nebulas, and trying to invade Rock and Mantis space was a horrible idea.
Your Saboteur says that Mantis are dumb without being prompted. It won't say anything more.
Your Saboteur admits it respects the training regimend followed by human soldiers.
Your Saboteur refuses to say where it recieved it's training from.

event.name: CREW_TALK_SABO_PROPHECY
event.text: Your Saboteur cuts you off mid-sentence and holds up a deck of tarot cards. "Ssssso captain, care to hear your fortune? I promissse, itsss legit. Only a sssmal fee too..."
You hand some scrap over to your Saboteur. This better be worth it...
The slug shuffles its cards, then lays 1 face down on the table and commands you to sit. "Let'ss sssee your card..."
The slug chuckles. "Next time, you don't get the captain'ssss dissscount..."
"Ah yesss, the Wheel of Fortune. Thisss one ssshould be sstraight forward, yessss? You ssshall soon come across a great fortune..."
"Interesssting, the Chariot... You will have great power ssssome day!"
"How ssssweet, the Empress. Today you will make a new friend!"
"Very fortunate for all of usss, you have drawn the Hierophant! Our misssion sssshall be blesssed by the guardian angelsss."
"Oh... thisss is the Hanged Man. Justicccce will be brought upon you for all your crimesss."
"My... thisss is the card of Death! One of ussss will not make it to tomorrow alive..."

removeCrew.text: You rush to your clonebay but it's already too late. The other crew tell you that they fell ill with a mysterious illness and they had to shut off the clonebay to prevent the spread of the infection.

event.text: "The Moon, the dark ssside of coursssse... are you afraid Captain? Becausssse you ssshould be..."
"Justice, the balanccccing force. Thingssss will be taken, but more will be given in return."

Your Orchid talks about its extreme fear of fire.
Your Orchid longs for real sunlight, and not just the artificial lights on the ship.
Your Orchid complains about your rule against them hypnotizing the other crew.
Your Orchid is busy decorating its quarters with vines.
Your Orchid wonders why you wouldn't vent all of the unnecessary rooms on the ship.
Your Orchid wishes it were stronger.

Your Orchid wonders what its like to have flesh.
You ask about the biological history of the evolution of Orchids. According to them, the first organism on their planet with brains were plants.
Your Orchid encourages that you become strictly carnivorous.
Your Orchid wants you to visit less hostile sectors.
Your Orchid wishes you had higher quality water aboard the ship.
Your Orchid wonders what its like to live alone as the Separatists do. They want to try it some time.
Your Orchid wants to build a greenhouse aboard the ship.

Your Ghost is impressed with how well you've managed to keep your ship in once piece.
Your Ghost asks why you're afraid of the destruction of this ship when you can just steal another one.
Your Ghost thinks the ship isnt crowded enough.
Your Ghost wonders if it would be cool to have AI holograms as crew.
Your Ghost comments that you can never have too many Ghosts on your ship.
You try to catch up with your ghost, but they always manage to slip past through the doors before you can open them.
Your Ghost wonders why it takes two of most aliens to have a child when all it needs is to expand large enough to multiply.
Your Ghost is trying to tear the paint off the walls of his quarters, so that he can see the comforting internals of the ship that it is so used to.
Your Ghost doesn't understand the concept of gender.
You try to teach your Ghost to dance, but it can't quite get the moves right. It blames its gaseous nature.
Your Ghost wants to someday be an architect, so that it can try and bring broken ships into style.
Your Ghost asks you to consider repainting all of the ship to vantablack.
Your Ghost contemplates the meaning of life.
Your Ghost encourages you to start building an armada out of stolen ships.
Your Ghost wonders what its like to have a family.

textList.name: TEXT_CREW_TALK_LANIUS
textList.text: You can't find your Lanius anywhere. You have to hope it isn't busy feasting on some important part of the ship.
Your Lanius tries to convince you that scrap makes an excellent, nutritious meal.
Your Lanius isn't sure how to hold a conversation. Your discussion mostly consists of you asking questions and it responding with one word answers that usually don't pertain at all to what you asked.
Your Lanius requests that if it is ever killed, you are to melt it's corpse into metal and turn it into a flak cannon.
Your Lanius asks why you won't just turn off the oxygen. You try to explain that other crew need to breathe, but it just doesn't comprehend.
Your Lanius makes no attempt to speak in a comprehensive language, and instead makes garbled noises that your translator can't even begin to convert.
Your Lanius wants to return to a nomadic life once this mission is over.
Your Lanius asks if it can shake your hand, understanding its a symbol of friendship between humans. You shake it's sharp blade arm cautiously, though you still end up cut.
Your Lanius doesn't understand why some people eat meat and plants when there is an unlimited supply of junk to feast upon.
You ask if your Lanius will help update your translator to understand it's language better, but have to stop when it tries to eat the device.
Your Lanius requests that you buy more flak cannons, and give it any of the left over ammunition for it to eat.
Your Lanius requests that it is paid in space junk instead of Federation currency when this mission is over.
Your Lanius doesn't care if it's on the good side of the bad side, as long as there's scrap for it to eat.
Your Lanius doesn't understand loyalty. It'll obey whoever is feeding it. You make a mental note to never let your Lanius negotiate with the Rebels.
Your Lanius doesn't understand why so many people dislike it's species.
Your Lanius advises you keep it away from the other crew, just in case the respirators malfunction.
Your Lanius asks why you won't just put on a space suit. You aren't sure of the answer yourself.
Your Lanius doesn't care to talk. It briefly asks if you have anything for it to eat before going back to sitting completely still.
Your Lanius hopes you will put more time into salvage missions, so that it will have more junk to eat.

event.name: CREW_TALK_LANIUS_REQUEST
event.text: Your Lanius appears to have a request. It asks if you will allow it access to the cargo bay and all the scrap inside.
You know why the Lanius wants in, and you aren't going to let it happen. They walk away pouting.
You open up the cargo-hold's doors and the Lanius leaps inside. They, as you excepted, consume a large portion of the scrap inside. You have to pull them back out before they eat everything inside.

You open up the cargo-hold's doors and the Lanius leaps inside. However to your surprise, instead of eating the scrap they reshape it into a sharp twisted structure. It appears your lanius has constructed a weapon!

textList.name: TEXT_CREW_TALK_WELDER
textList.text: Your attempts at communicating with your Welder fail. You aren't even sure if the gibberish they're making is a real language or actually incomprehensible nonsense.
Contrary to their name, your Welder has few skills when it comes to actual welding. They can however make a nice souffle.
Your Welder explains that its red color comes from rust, which naturally develops on their bodies. It's often considered a status symbol in Lanius society.
It's fortunate that metal beings don't have body odour, because you notice that your Welder has not showered once the entire mission.
Your Welder requests that any unused resources from the mission are given to it so that it may have a victory banquet.
You lecture your Welder about eating the ship after catching it trying to eat some electronics labelled as "very important, do not touch".
Your Welder offers to be used as a projectile if ever deemed necessary. They seem very eager about it, actually.
Your Welder wonders why so many races end with "man", yet Lanius are not referred to as "Metalmen".
You accidentally brush against the Welder, cutting yourself on the spikes. They apologize, and recommend you clean the wound immediately.

You enter your Welders private chambers and are startled by the floating pair of glowing eyes in the darkness. You quickly turn on the lights, and remind yourself you can always bring your Welder along in case the flashlight runs out of batteries.
Your Welder finds comfort in working in close-quarters. Its unfortunate that other races don't feel the same, not eager to be impaled on the sharp spikes.
Your Welder requests assistance in sharpening the spikes long their body. You awkwardly agree to assist.
Your Welder requests some oil or grease to lubricate its rusty joints.
Your Welder complements you on your military prowess, and your ability to employ strategies that don't involve launching the crew out of a flak launcher to eat the enemy ship.
Your Welder looks forward to the next mass-hibernation of the Lanius race, though they will miss the action of serving on a ship like yours.
Your Welder refuses to explain the science behind how Lanius drain oxygen.
Your Welder boasts about the efficiency of its oxygen draining abilities, claiming that it takes a full squad of orchids to outcompete it.
You cannot find your Welder, and the computer informs you they took a brief bathroom trip out in the vacuum of space.

Your Welder dislikes the constant attention that the Lanius race receives from nosy researchers, biologists, cultists, mechanics, journalists, government officials, tax collectors, and various other occupations that you can't fathom how they relate.

Your Crystal knows many of its friends decided to stay behind in the old Crystal homeworlds. It left after being unable to tollerate the persistant waves of pioneers coming to explore.
Your Crystal thinks the war between the Federation and Rebellion is pointless, and doesn't understand why humans don't just isolate themselves before they start more wars.
Your Crystal encourages you to install more layers of protection on the hull.
Your Crystal advises you to avoid using missiles due to their cost inneficiency.
Your Crystal has barracaded themselves in their quarters with a thick layer of crystals. You're unable to get through.
Your Crystal wonders why you need doors when you have him to lock out intruders.
Your Crystal asks if you have any secret abilities lying in wait.
Your Crystal requests that you designate a room specifically for growing crystals in.
Your Crystal tries to explain to you the process of growing crystals, but you're lost early on.
Your Crystal thinks you are dignified enough for it to be satisfied with having you in command.
Your Crystal wonders what it would be like to command its own fleet.
Your Crystal dissaproves of the Rebellion ever since the invaded the original Crystal homeworlds in large numbers.
Your Crystal wants to try building an entire ship out of its own freshly grown crystals someday.
Your Crystal thinks you need to diversify your crew even more.
Your Crystal politely requests that you not talk to it.
Your Crystal thinks proper manners are the most important thing in the galaxy.
Your Crystal secretly confesses it misses all of the shrines worshipping its kind in the Rock Sacred Grounds before the Lost Suns converted it into their stronghold.

textList.name: TEXT_CREW_TALK_ANCIENT
textList.text: Your Ancient marvels at how long your species has managed to survive without destroying themselves.
Your Ancient reflects on how boring it was that everything was a cube in it's home sector, and thinks its a welcome change to see ships with some curves.
Your Ancient wishes it was a Royal. It thinks black is a rather bland color, and white would really spruce things up.
You ask your Ancient if it has a gender. It informs you that it does not, ever since the ancients built their "perfect" mechanical bodies.
Your Ancient explains they once had a body, but all Ancients eventually transfer their consience to a robotic form.
Your Ancient enjoys beating people to a bloody pulp with it's spinning cubes.
You ask your Ancients a few questions about how their cubical appendages work. Your Ancient explains the cubes just do what it wants, because science and stuff.
Your Ancient thinks you're pretty ok for a mortal.
Your Ancient explains that it percieves the world in 5D. You're curious to learn more but fearful for your mental health.
You try to get your Ancient to explain some phrases in its native language. It refuses, not wanting to reduce your frontal lobe to a puddle.
Your Ancient wonders why you don't simply install your translator into your brain rather than carry it with you.

Your Ancient laughs at your innability to survive in a vacuum, and when it gets no response, attempts to brag even further by ejecting itself out the airlock. You have to gather the entire crew to help pull them back in.
Your Ancient doesn't understand why you like your fleshy body so much.
Your Ancient explains it has a morbid fear of hexagons. It won't say why.
Your Ancient thinks you should replace all of your current weapons with even better weapons. It advices you use Ancient tech.
Your Ancient asks why you don't just build an artificial planet and slingshot it into the Rebel Flagship. It thinks that would be a much more interesting and worthwhile method of destroying it/
Your Ancient finds interest in the wide diversity between the different species in the Galactic stage. It wonders how long it will be till you're all extinct.
Your Ancient thinks you need to give the crew less time to sleep and more time working on a reality simulation that it's been trying to convince you to create.
Your Ancient desperately swats at an insect that somehow managed to make it way into your ship, but it keeps missing with it's cubes.

textList.name: TEXT_CREW_TALK_ROYAL
textList.text: Your Ancient enjoys being able to tell people what to do, though it respects your position as captain.
Your Ancient hates how slow it repairs, admitting there are some downsides to only having cubes for limbs.
Your Ancient misses the Ancient Homeworlds and the beautiful artificial planets there.
Your Ancient has caught word of Slug Pleasure Cruises, and intends to splurge on one some day.

There are few things left that your Ancient wants to do before it dies, but one of them is to take down a genocidal uprising. Luckily, it just so happens to have ended up on the perfect ship for such a thing.
Your Ancient thinks you should invest more into everything.
Your Ancient has heard stories of human children being given blocks with colorful letters printed on them. It desires to obtain some.
Your Ancient dearly apologizes for your unborn baby brother. When you ask what it means, it lets out a robotic cough and floats away.
You ask you Ancient if it can speak in any accent. It confirms that it indeed can, but that it cannot demonstrate them all, as it would take longer than the Universe has left to live.
Your Ancient thinks all types of modern tech are facinating, but think finds Ancient tech superior.
Your Ancient wonders what foods taste like. It tires of feeding on heat energy and plasma.
Your Ancient does not want to get political about the color of its mechanical form.
Your Ancient wants to someday test just how fast it can spin without destroying itself or disrupting the fabric of space-time.
Your Ancient makes a joke about percieving reality in 4D, but quickly realises your bain is not yet able to comprehend it.
You ask your Ancient what size its original form was. It asks if it can see a picture of the terran moon to compare.

Your Ancient explains that the Royals were in charge of commanding fleets and giving orders. Its ironic because all Ancients are so far superior to other organisms that its impossible for any of them to be better than the other.
Your Ancient explains other Ancients willingly obey their Royals. It recommends you do the same.
Your Ancient is curious to see if it can construct a hadron particle collider with the supplies on-board this ship.
Your Ancient desires to have a pet some day, so it can test what plane of reality it can survive on until its brain melts.
